subject: Learning
title: Screen Time and Young Learners
description: A quick, practical guide to Screen Time and Young Learners.

hook.text: A toddler learns a word from a person in 1 minute. The same word from a screen takes 10 repetitions. The gap is real.

buildup.text: The 'video deficit effect' shows that children under 3 learn significantly less from screens than from live interaction.

discovery.text: Live interaction provides contingent feedbackâ€”the speaker adjusts to the child's reactions. Screens can't do that.

twist.text: Video calls with a responsive adult partially close the gapâ€”it's the interaction, not the medium, that matters.

climax.text: For older children, quality content with active engagement can support learning. Passive consumption rarely helps.

punchline.text: Screens can't replace people. But people using screens wisely can still connect.

quiz.question: What is the video deficit effect?
options: Children under 3 learn significantly less from screens than from live interaction
Children learn equally well from all media formats
Video always enhances learning for young children
